title: Franco Navarro
text:
Franco Enrique Navarro Monteiro (born 10 November 1961) is a Peruvian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and former player who played as a <a href="Striker%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a>. He is the current manager of <a href="Universidad%20T%C3%A9cnica%20de%20Cajamarca">UTC</a>.
Club career.
Navarro played for <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Independiente">Independiente</a> from Argentina , <a href="Club%20Centro%20Deportivo%20Municipal">Deportivo Municipal</a>, <a href="Sporting%20Cristal">Sporting Cristal</a>, <a href="Alianza%20Lima">Alianza Lima</a> from Peru and <a href="FC%20Wettingen">FC Wettingen</a> from Switzerland among others. He retired in 1995.
International career.
He was a prolific goal scorer and a participant at the <a href="1982%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1982 FIFA World Cup</a>. He was also member of the <a href="Peru%20national%20football%20team">Peru national football team</a> for the qualification stages of the World Cup in <a href="1986%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">Mexico (1986)</a> and Italy (1990). Navarro played a total of 56 games for Peru between 1980 and 1989, scoring 16 goals. He made his debut on 18 July 1980 in a <a href="Exhibition%20game">friendly</a> against <a href="Uruguay%20national%20football%20team">Uruguay</a> (0–0) in <a href="Montevideo">Montevideo</a>. His last game was on 27 August 1989 against Uruguay at a FIFA World Cup Qualifier.
He is remembered for the leg-breaking incident five minutes into the deciding qualifier game between Argentina and Peru in the <a href="1986%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1986 FIFA World Cup</a> in Mexico. The <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> defender <a href="Juli%C3%A1n%20Camino">Julián Camino</a> broke Navarro’s leg with a tackle. Camino was not expelled from the game. Argentina with <a href="Ricardo%20Gareca">Ricardo Gareca</a> tied the game 2–2 and qualified to the World Cup; Argentina would go on to win the 1986 World Cup.
Coaching career.
He has been a coach for several Peruvian teams, including <a href="Sporting%20Cristal">Sporting Cristal</a>, <a href="Alianza%20Lima">Alianza Lima</a>, and <a href="Cienciano">Cienciano</a> as well as the <a href="Peru%20national%20football%20team">Peru national football team</a>.
